comments.text:
+Ben A I agree with you absolutely. And I understand your displeasure 
towards bad jokes for shock value and I am with you in standing up for 
others. Though I must say that I think little of it has to do with the 
comedian's punchline or the musical performer's lyrics, but by the lack of 
social love and understanding taught to children by people who have no 
concept of it. I believe this because, in my opinion, the best jokes are 
often at someones expense. But the worst jokes are at the expense of those 
who cannot defend themselves. Music is different to me because I only enjoy 
music that lyrically involves love or instrumentals that evoke emotion. 
Other than that I completely agree with you.
comments.author: Clarence Weatherwax

comments.text:
+Clarence Weatherwax today it seems like popular culture really has become 
very callous. Many modern comedians and comedies of today use many 
references two special needs children and make the short bus jokes and use 
the word retard. It is as though they are trying to take advantage of the 
backlash against political correctness, which I am completely against (I 
hate p.c. bullshit), but they use terminologies such as this for shock 
value. I understand this mentality completely because it didn't bother me 
until I had a special needs child. So eff the trolls and I am never one to 
infringe on freedom of speech, but each of us can make a difference if we 
stand up and do something as simple as speak up when someone is belittling 
another who is incapable of helping their situation.

top_comment.text:
20 Years Old And 35 Inches Tall

Miniature man Nick Smith, 20, from Jefferson, Georgia, USA, stands at just 
35 inches tall - even though both his brothers are a whopping 6ft 5ins. He 
is one of only a handful of people worldwide - around 100 individuals - 
with a rare genetic condition called primordial dwarfism. Nick has a 
version called Osteodysplastic Primordial Dwarfism, Type II (MOPD II), and 
is the size of a three year old, weighing less than two stone. 

#dwarfism   #primordialdwarfism   #dwarf  ﻿

+trollworkout I like your way of defending your opinion and, from your

information, I think he/she was right, this tiny person”s brain hasn”t 
developed and it”s really exaggerated to claim he can live on his own. In 
answer to your question, it states in the video that he has strokes and 
brain aneurysm. Given that fact only, he needs 24/7 supervision, so your 
idea of him living in a neighbor house can be easily considered as 
inefficient. Now, I agree with you that he is treated like a child and 
maybe if he was treated more like an adult, he would at least develop 
mentally to the age of 10 let”s say. But why is living like a child a bad 
thing? He is obviously happy. I mean, we think that being mentally 
normal/mature is a good thing. We could be wrong. We  don”t know what it”s 
actually like because we never experienced mental ”recession” as adults and 
we only pity him or people like him because we know they are not healthy 
and normal. He could be happier than most of us.For example,  I think that 
the childhood was the nicest period of my life and I felt the happiest. Of 
course, as you said, it”s your opinion and also, it”s not that absurd to 
try to integrate him in the society. My opinion is that his family treats 
him right. But I liked how you sustained your ideas with arguments, 
although I think that I could dismantle all of them if the both of us were 
at a public debate, let”s say. :)

pills...lol.) Also I never said that they did not teach English; I did say 
that they did not teach grammar or phonics.

In the 1980's there was a "better" way of teaching kids spelling then 
phonics but it was only taught in a few schools and only for a few years 
because they learned that it was doing kids more harm then good because 
then they could not "sound-out" words like when taught the phonics system.

year we could have Texas and US History classes starting in first grade

captions.text:
00:00
COMM: Like a real life Peter Pan, Nick Smith
will never grow up.

00:07
Aged 20 and only 35 inches tall, he's one
of the world's smallest men.

00:15
Here in Jefferson, Georgia, Nick's family

are in a race against time to give him the
best life they can.

00:23
Shelly: He to me is still that child that

never really grew up. He still loves every
holiday, believes in Santa Claus, believes
in the Easter Bunny, Halloween.

00:35
COMM: He's one of only a handful of people

worldwide suffering from Primordial Dwarfism
and most don't make it past their 20s.

00:42
Shelly: The biggest thing is a want him to
feel that he is just like everyone else.

00:49
COMM: While the condition has given him a

tiny stature, Nick's two brothers, Levi and
Travis, tower over him at a huge six foot
five inches each.

01:00
Shelly: He requires and wants a little bit

more from me than the other brothers, you
know, they've gone ahead and they've grown
up. Their needs are more met and they've matured.

01:11
We have this connection, it's an unbelievable

connection, just this bond. I can't even imagine
day without him.

01:17
You're my superhero, aren't you?

01:21
COMM: Nick is in his final year of high school,

where he gets a special education to prepare
him for life after school.

01:30
At school, tiny Nick is a big character.

01:32
Julie: Nick does not see any difference between

himself and anyone else. There are times when
he'll say 'I'm as tall as you are!' and we

say 'Yeah, you're tall', but he truly doesn't
see that he's any different than anybody else.

01:49
Nick: Boo!

01:55
Woman: What you doing? How are you? That was
a good hug.

02:00
He comes in every morning up here and greets

us with a smile and some pushups and some
muscles, you know, gives us some great big
strong hugs.

02:11
He's definitely a ladies man.

02:25
COMM: Alongside his small stature, Nick's

condition means he faces a number of health
risks - like strokes, brain aneurisms and
ongoing kidney problems.

02:36
Shelly: Nick is such a happy person and the

medical part of it is just something that
we have to do unfortunately. No-one wants

to go through it, but we want to have the
most normal life as we possibly can.

02:52
You want to talk to Hannah?

02:53
Nick: Yeah, Hannah.

02:54
Shelly: All the way in Minnesota?

02:55
Nick: Yeah, Minnesota

02:56
COMM: To help manage the health risks, Shelly

and other parents around the world share information
to safeguard their children and try and prolong
their lives.

03:05
Shelly: Hey, so you're out of school now today?

03:08
When somebody's gone through the same situation

as you have, it does give you a little bit
of comfort knowing that, you know, you're

gonna get through it and you're not the only
one who's walked that walk.

03:17
Mom: Love you guys

03:18
Shelly: You have a great day. Have fun at
ballerina.

03:21
COMM: While they're not dealing with medical

challenges, or educating Nick for his adult
life, the family focus on making sure he enjoys
life to the fullest.

03:32
Levi: That's cheating!

03:37
Shelly: We want all our kids to have a happy

life, but the biggest thing is I want him
to feel that he is just like everyone else,
and he is.

03:51
He still lives in I think in a beautiful place.

It's kind of not reality, but it's in his
world. He's still going to achieve and be

whoever he wants to be and that to me is a
beautiful thing.

04:04
Nick: Beat that! Beat that!

04:11
Shelly: Up on the bed so I can get you your
medicines.

04:16
To me, he's still that child who never really
grew up.

04:20
Sweet dreams. Don't let the bedbugs bite.

04:23
Nick: Yeah, yeah.

04:24
Shelly: See you later, alligator. I love you.

04:27
Nick: I love you too mum.

04:29
Shelly: See you in the morning.
